message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest asthma, and methacholine is used as a bronchoconstrictor in a methacholine challenge test to diagnose asthma. A reduction in peak expiratory flow rate after administration of methacholine confirms the diagnosis of asthma. Atenolol and Ipratropium bromide are used to treat asthma, not to diagnose it. Methoxyflurane is a general anesthetic and not used for asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of shortness of breath and dry cough suggest asthma, and the administration of a drug that reduces the peak expiratory flow rate confirms the diagnosis. Methacholine is a drug that is used in bronchial challenge testing to diagnose asthma. Atenolol is a beta-blocker that is not used in the treatment of asthma. Ipratropium bromide is a bronchodilator that is used in the treatment of asthma but would not have caused a reduction in peak expiratory flow rate. Methoxyflurane is a volatile anesthetic that is used in general anesthesia and would not have been administered in this setting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest possible asthma, and methacholine is used in bronchial challenge tests to diagnose asthma. The drug causes bronchoconstriction, resulting in a reduced peak expiratory flow rate in patients with asthma. Atenolol is a beta blocker used in hypertension and heart failure. Ipratropium bromide is an anticholinergic used in the treatment of bronchospasm associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Methoxyflurane is a volatile anesthetic that is no longer used in the United States.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest asthma, and the fact that the peak expiratory flow rate decreased after drug administration suggests the drug was Methacholine, which is used to diagnose asthma by inducing bronchoconstriction. Atenolol is a beta-blocker and not used in asthma treatment. Ipratropium bromide is a bronchodilator usually used in COPD, and Methoxyflurane is a general anesthetic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation appear to suggest asthma, which is confirmed by the administration of methacholine, which causes bronchoconstriction in asthmatics. Atenolol and ipratropium bromide are used to treat asthma but do not reactivate asthma symptoms. Methoxyflurane is a general anesthesia agent and is not used to treat asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history suggests asthma, and the administration of Methacholine is used to diagnose asthma. It is a bronchoconstrictor that, if positive, results in a reduction in peak expiratory flow rate. All other options are not used to diagnose or treat asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest asthma and the administration of a drug that caused a reduced peak expiratory flow rate suggests Methacholine, which is used in bronchoprovocation tests to diagnose asthma. Atenolol and Ipratropium bromide are used to treat asthma, while Methoxyflurane is an anesthetic agent.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest asthma. Methacholine is a drug used in bronchial provocation testing to help diagnose asthma. If the drug causes a reduction in peak expiratory flow rate, it is a positive result for asthma. Atenolol is a beta-blocker and can worsen asthma symptoms. Ipratropium bromide is used to treat asthma, but it would not cause a reduction in peak expiratory flow rate. Methoxyflurane is a general anesthetic and would not be used to treat asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest asthma as a possible diagnosis. Methacholine is a drug used for bronchial provocation testing to diagnose asthma, and a positive test result indicates airway hyperresponsiveness. A reduced peak expiratory flow rate after administering the drug confirms the diagnosis of asthma. Atenolol, ipratropium bromide, and methoxyflurane are not typically used in the diagnosis or treatment of asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest asthma, and the drug that is commonly used to diagnose asthma in children is methacholine. A reduced peak expiratory flow rate after administering methacholine confirms the diagnosis of asthma. Atenolol is a beta-blocker, ipratropium bromide is an anticholinergic medication used to treat COPD, and methoxyflurane is a general anesthetic.
